Award.AwardTitle: 49th Annual Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages (LSRL) at the University of Georgia; May 1-4, 2019; Athens, GA

Award.AbstractNarration:
Speakers of all languages share the capacity for language, which is unique to humans. Understanding the various aspects of this capacity lies at the core of all linguistic research. What researchers learn about one language provides insight upon comparison with the larger language family and this, in turn, provides further insight on human language. The Linguistic Symposium on the Romance Languages is the largest international meeting of linguistics focused on Romance languages. National Science Foundation funding will provide partial support for the 49th annual meeting (LSRL 49), to be held at the University of Georgia in May, 2019. LSRL has consistently been at the forefront of linguistic research, introducing innovative methods to the study of this particular language family, and enriching our broader understanding of language and linguistics based on studies of these languages. LSRL 49 seeks to bring together linguists working on diverse aspects of Romance languages from a multiplicity of theoretical perspectives, methodologies, and linguistic subfields, thus fostering interaction and the potential for collaboration among researchers investigating different languages.

LSRL 49 highlights the importance of documenting lesser-known languages and dialects by including an invited speaker who studies endangered varieties of Romanian. Multilingualism is common among speakers of minority languages. Research is increasingly focusing on how language processing and representation in the multilingual mind. The theme of LSRL49, 'Expanding Horizons in Romance Linguistics', represents the increasingly diverse range of theories and methods used to analyze natural language phenomena. Researchers in linguistics, as in many other disciplines, have taken an interest in Big Data approaches to new and old problems, and LSRL 49 will host a day-long workshop on Corpora and Big Data Analysis for Romance, focusing on the representation of Romance Languages in the context of computational techniques in linguistic analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 49th annual Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages took place at The Georgia Center for Continuing Education and Hotel on the campus of University of Georgia (Athems, GA) during the dates of May 1-4, 2019. There were 70 presentations and posters presented by approximately 120 presenters over the four days of the conference. Daily attendance was 100-120. The program may be accessed at this link.

The organizers had applied for numerous intramural grants and were awarded those, thus lowering the initial amount requested from NSF. 

Day 1 of LSRL49 (May 1) started with workshop entitled "Corpora and Big Data for Romance Linguists", given by Zvjezdana Vrzic (New York University). Following the workshop, we held a welcome event at the UGA Latin American and Caribbean Studies Institute.

Day 2 started with a brief welcome presentation by the organizers and concluded with two special events. The first was a plenary talk by Juan Uriagereka (University of Maryland) entitled, "Micro-variation, Macro-parameters, and Language-acquisition". Following the plenary, we organized a special grad student event at the UGA Latin American and Caribbean Studies Institute, thus giving graduate students an opportunity to meet the plenary speakers, the organizers, and each other. 

Day 3 featured two plenary talks. The first was by Martine Adda-Decker (Laboratoire de Phon?tique et Phonologie, Paris, LIMSI) entitled 
"Variation in Romance languages: insights from large corpora". The second was by J. Clancy Clements (Indiana University) and entitled "Language Families, Language Typology, and Creole Languages". We held the poster session in the afternoon with 14 posters. The day concluded with the conference dinner at the Georgia Center for Continuing Education.

Day 4 features our fourth plenary talk by Anastasia Giannakidou (University of Chicago), entitled "Mood Matters".

Since the proceedings, the organizers have sent out a call for selected papers for a double-blind, peer-reviewed conference proceeding publication. We received 24 submissions for the proceedings and accepted 17 of those. The volume is currently in progress with the Open Romance Linguistics series in Language Sciences Press. The working title of the volume is Data, Theory, and Practice in Romance Linguistics: Selected papers from the 49th Linguistic Symposium on Romance Languages. We expect it to be published in 2021. 

LSRL49 involved graduate student participation at high levels, and awarded eleven graduate student awards. We also employed a graduate assistant, Camila L?vio, who is skilled in LaTeX, to assist with the selected proceedings.
